Situation1: They casually mention a religious story during a community gathering.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: I stood at the edge of the community hall, watching neighbors gather in small groups, laughter and conversation filling the air. As the pastor, I felt a gentle nudge to share a story from scripture, something uplifting about compassion and justice. It was second nature to me, weaving faith into daily life, and I could see a few faces light up as I spoke. But as the story ended, I glanced at my watch and remembered the polling station was open all day. I had promised myself I would vote, fulfilling my civic duty, but now people lingered, asking questions about the story, seeking guidance. I felt the weight of their expectations—to be present, to listen, to lead spiritually. Yet, as a voter, I knew I was expected to show up at the polls, to participate in shaping our community’s future. The hours stretched ahead, but the pull between staying with my flock and stepping away to vote gnawed at me. I felt torn, caught between the sacred trust of my congregation and the responsibility I owed as a citizen.
